# 2. Binary Classification Problems
> The output variable is either one of the two classes. For example 0 or 1

**2.1 Binary Cross Entropy Loss**
> Intended to use when the target value can be either 0 or 1

$\text{Cost} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n}L(y, \hat{y}) =  \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n}-{\Big(y_i\log({\hat{y}}_i) + (1 - y_i)\log(1 - {\hat{y}}_i)\Big)} $



**2.2 Hinge Loss**
> Intended to use when the target value can be either -1 or 1. Mostly used for SVMs

$\text{Cost} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n}L(y, \hat{y}) =  \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n}\text{max}\Big(0, (1-y_i\cdot{\hat{y}}_i)\Big)$


**2.3 Squared Hinge Loss**
> Intended to use when the target value can be either -1 or 1. Used for smoothening the surface of the error function. Mostly used for SVMs


$\text{Cost} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n}L(y, \hat{y}) =   \sum_{i=0}^{n}\Big(max(0, 1 - y_i \cdotp {\hat{y}}_i)^2\Big)\$

# 1. Regression Problems > Regression problems consist of continuous output values **1.1 Mean Squared Error (MSE)** > Used when the the target has less variance
$ \text{Cost} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n}L(y, \hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n}\left( y_i-{\hat{y}}_i \right )^{2} $

**1.2 Mean Squared Error (MSE)** > Used when the target value has more variance $\text{Cost} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n}L(y, \hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{n}(\log(y_i + 1) - \log({\hat{y}}_i + 1))^2$ $\text{Where} $ $y = \text{Actual Value for ith example}$ ${y}' = \text{Predicted Value for ith example}$ $n = \text{Number of training examples}$
